steps.description: 1. Treat the image as a 3×3 tic‑tac‑toe of interior cells separated by the two maroon bars (bars run along columns 5 and 11 and rows 5 and 11 in the 17×17 grid). Each interior cell is a 5×5 pixel block (rows 0–4, 6–10, 12–16 and same for columns).

2. Build a single 5×5 “pattern mask” equal to the logical OR of every non‑grid colored pixel (any cell value ≠ 0 and ≠ grid‑bar value) found in any interior cell. In other words mark a mask pixel as active if that relative pixel position is occupied in at least one of the nine cells.

3. For each of the nine 5×5 interior cells, apply the mask: for every active mask pixel, if that relative pixel was already occupied in that particular cell keep its original color (value 2); otherwise fill that pixel with the maroon/grid color (value 8). Do not write into the bar rows/columns (the separators) and do not change background zeros elsewhere.

4. Leave all original grid bars unchanged and preserve any original colored pixels that were already present (they stay value 2). The result is every cell showing the same combined shape (the union mask); original pixels remain red (2) while newly added pixels use the maroon color (8).
